InfoText: After finishing this lesson,  you will be able to...
[ encode and decode airlines.
[ encode and decode cities and airports.
[ encode and decode equipment.
[ encode and decode countries.
<PgDn>
The term itinerary refers to all the departure points,  connecting points,  and
destinations in a trip. The following itinerary consists of 2 segments:
1.^Paris^ -^ London^
2.^London^ -^ Paris^
This itinerary is a round trip. The first segment is called the outbound
segment,  and the second segment is called the return segment.
<PgDn>
City codes and airport codes are used to indicate the board point and off
point of each segment,  as follows:
MADPAR^
Board point~~~~{  }~~~~Off point
This city pair would indicate a segment from Madrid (MAD to Paris (PAR.
<PgDn>
The transaction code DAN^ is used to encode a city,  as follows:
DAN^MADRID
Encode city~~~~{   }~~~~City name
This entry will display the city code for Madrid. Input this entry now.

TerminalText: A:ARPT B:BUS C:CITY D:DUAL H:HELIPORT O:OFF-PT R:RAIL S:ASSOC.
InfoText: The response gives the 3-letter IATA code,  the code indicator,  and the
name. The C after the code indicates that the code is a city code. The A
in the next line indicates the airport code. The country code is shown on
the far right. Now encode the city Munich.

TerminalText: A:ARPT B:BUS C:CITY D:DUAL H:HELIPORT O:OFF-PT R:RAIL S:ASSOC.
InfoText: The transaction code DAC^ is used to decode a city or airport code,  as
follows:
DAC^FLR
Decode city~~~~{  }~~~~City code
Input this entry now.

TerminalText: A:ARPT B:BUS C:CITY D:DUAL H:HELIPORT O:OFF-PT R:RAIL S:ASSOC.
InfoText: Now input the entry to decode the city code DUR.

TerminalText: A:ARPT B:BUS C:CITY D:DUAL H:HELIPORT O:OFF-PT R:RAIL S:ASSOC.
InfoText: Encode the city Bremen.

TerminalText: A:ARPT B:BUS C:CITY D:DUAL H:HELIPORT O:OFF-PT R:RAIL S:ASSOC.
InfoText: Now input the entry to decode the city code PAR.

TerminalText: A:ARPT B:BUS C:CITY D:DUAL H:HELIPORT O:OFF-PT R:RAIL S:ASSOC.
InfoText: Some cities have multiple airports. In this case,  each airport has a
different code. In this example,  PAR is the city code for Paris,  whereas
CDG is the code for the Charles de Gaulle airport. Now encode the city
Barcelona.

TerminalText: A:ARPT B:BUS C:CITY D:DUAL H:HELIPORT O:OFF-PT R:RAIL S:ASSOC.
InfoText: Each airline has a two-letter code. To encode an airline,  type DNA^ followed
by the airline's name,  as follows:
DNA^AMERICA WEST
Encode airline~~~~{      }~~~~Airline name
This entry will display the airline code for America West. Input this entry.
The response shows the 2-letter carrier code,  the 3-letter code,  the
3-digit numeric code,  and the name of the airline. The transaction code
DNA^ is also used to decode an airline code,  as follows:
DNA^CX
This entry will decode the airline code CX. Input this entry now.
Now decode the airline code OS.
Encode the airline Aer Lingus.
Decode the airline code JU.
Each passenger aircraft has a three-letter equipment code. The transaction
code DNE^ is used to encode aircraft equipment,  as follows:
DNE^FOKKER F27
This entry will display the equipment code for Fokker F27 aircraft. Input
this entry now.
The entry code DNE^ is also used to decode an equipment code,  as follows:
DNE^DH8
Decode the equipment code M80.
Encode the equipment Cessna.
Now decode the equipment code GRG.
The entry code DC^ is used to encode or decode a country,  as follows:
DC^JAPAN
This entry will display the country code for Japan. Input this entry now.
The response shows the 2-letter country code,  the country name,  the
region,  and the IATA traffic conference area. The ISO currency code is
also displayed. The transaction code DC^ is also used to decode a country
Input the entry to decode the country code IT.
Let's review. Encode the airline Egyptair.
Display the city code for Brussels.
Decode the carrier code AY.
Decode the city code STR.

TerminalText: A:ARPT B:BUS C:CITY D:DUAL H:HELIPORT O:OFF-PT R:RAIL S:ASSOC.
InfoText: Decode the equipment code 744.
Display the country code for Canada.
